text: Every enlightened and civilised society must offer accommodation for travellers. Where tea is available, conversation and wisdom surely follow – for a price, of course.
To understand the enemy, one must be amongst the enemy, and know the enemy.
Animal tamers who know the hearts of beasts as well as people recognise and encourage potential in them, raising steeds worthy of heroes.
Ports are the tributaries of healthy trade and can be further developed to increase the import and export of goods.
New and dependable tools reduce physical effort and increase productivity, improving the results of labour.
Weaponsmiths who dedicate everything to their art at the expense of all else forge weapons worthy of the mightiest talents.
Tea is aromatic, calming and aids contemplation; the harvesting of the tea plants here will bring much income to the area.
The Zhong combine the administrative experience of their Yuan lineage with the vigour of a new dynasty carved out of sheer ambition.
Taxes are immutable, funding invaluable public works and infrastructure. The people, however, do not see things the same way.
Salt is the mineral of life and commerce; a staple that is always in demand, providing an industry that attracts workers to the area.
Even with a standing army, the realm’s stability must be assured by drawing bodies from the population – willingly or otherwise!
The land is rife with potential; it can be developed to accommodate markets for trading or farms to increase crop yields.
Without inheriting authority, wealth's greatest use is for attaining power, so the brave can serve China regardless of their heritage.
Forges produce improved equipment for your troops, the materials boost to your income.
New and dependable tools reduce physical effort and increase productivity, improving the results of labour.
Grain is good; the very essence of life across the land.
Taoism teaches the people how to be content; this happiness is evident in everything the people produce.
Copper is as flexible in its uses as in its actual physical properties and can be mined to make weapons, art and coins.
Xiliang supply lines use foraging techniques and mounted troops to deliver provisions, while simultaneously disrupting supply routes for trespassing armies.
Ports are the tributaries of healthy trade and can be further developed to increase the import and export of goods.
Let the spirit flow through you and enlightenment will follow.
A Shu-Han tax administration oversees the collection of taxes with the good of the people in mind, ensuring all pay a fair and equal share.
The Kong family rightfully claim Confucius as an ancestor, and fittingly, their schools promote enlightenment and poetry for financial and cultural betterment.
Iron is heaven’s will made manifest, and this area is rich with it, boosting your industry and improving the quality of weapons.
Places to reflect, and pause, and give thanks and offering to those far beyond our understanding.
Before growth can happen, sickness must be cured.
Divergent paths grant new opportunities - administration of the Han Empire, sanctuary for the expelled, or riches from banditry.
A recruitment infrastructure is vital for swelling the ranks of the resistance.
Tradition is more powerful than any army, if wielded in the right manner.
A military infrastructure is vital for supplying your forces; it can be further developed to increase stockpiles and military preparedness.
Laws are the pillars that hold civilisation aloft. Without them we succumb to corruption, baser instincts and chaos.
A warrior on horseback is worth several on foot; the horses bred and trained by the tribespeople here are more effective in battle.
The promise of homes for labourers will attract people seeking stability against chaos.
Industry and commerce can be improved by producing finely-crafted artistic items that also protect against evil and promote the Tao.
That which the labourer needs must be made by the skilled artisan, the trained crafter – only the finest tools will do!
Animal tamers who know the hearts of beasts as well as people recognise and encourage potential in them, raising steeds worthy of heroes.
Work provides a living wage, and the promise of homes for labourers will attract people to the area seeking stability against chaos.
Privately-run workshops produce finely-crafted artistic items, boosting your economy from the industry and commerce generated.
Strong walls and ready warriors bar the narrow passage, and vow to defend it to the last.
The administration office is the seat of power in the commandery, and the decisions and statutes made here determine the destiny of the realm.
The administrative and economic centre of the commandery, and home to a large part of its population.
Animals, a resource in themselves, have many uses. Rearing livestock provides a reliable source of food and income for the people.
The sea provides, be it food or income; sold at market or served at the table, the fish caught here benefit all.
By educating the people in the Way of Reason, corruption is eradicated and harmony established.
Places to sing, and dance, and while away the hours in social merriment.
Soldiers farm the land to supply food for your armies, simultaneously defending it and increasing the food yield in the area.
To find certain items in this world, one must look in less conventional places.
Grain storage protects the harvest from thieves, pests and natural disasters, providing food during sieges and supply for your armies.
Fertile soil and light rainfall lends this area to growing grain, providing work and food for the people.
The vast paddies spread as far as the eye can see, cascading down the steps unending fields of life.

Bandits have little time for the hypocrisy of so-called warlords; these tribute buildings provide a place for vassals to pay their respect – in gold.
A marketplace provides the aspiring and veteran merchants alike with a place to sell local wares and goods.
The land is rife with potential; it can be developed to accommodate markets for trading or farms to increase crop yields.
This area is heavily forested; this abundant source of timber makes construction here less expensive.
Conscription raises troops from the population for the great cause, increasing the replenishment and the mustering of bodies across your commanderies.

Education offers knowledge for the enlightenment of all, so that things are learned and understood more easily.
Tea is aromatic, calming and aids contemplation; the harvesting of the tea plants here will bring much income to the area.
When fighting a greater opponent, remain flexible and use cunning and surprise.
A well-organised system improves the efficiency of tax collection across rural areas, where administrative matters are often harder to carry out.
Armourers who are masters in their field create pieces fit for the greatest warriors and occasionally even an emperor.
Conscription raises troops from the population for the great cause, increasing replenishment across your commanderies.
Conscription raises troops from the population, improving the efficiency of agricultural garrisons and increasing replenishment across your commanderies.
Economic stability through industry lends resources to the Yellow Turban cause.
Harbours provide livelihoods and trade and can be further developed with an eye on greater profits or larger fishing hauls.
Under heaven, all people are equal.
Weary travellers pay handsomely for a place to rest, and should tea be available, will learn much from contemplation while taking refreshment.
Make room for nature and pleasure.
Bamboo thrives in this area’s climate; the cultivation of the timber makes construction here less expensive.
There are none perfect in the world; only intentions are perfect.
Government support provides homes for workers and can further benefit the land with improved irrigation or new tools for farming.
Soldiers farm the land to supply food for your armies, simultaneously defending it and increasing the food yield in the area.
The Tian guides us, through understanding of the self, to a life beyond.
The heavy rainfall here is perfect for growing rice, providing the necessary work, food and income.
Silk is one of China’s finest riches; a desirable commodity both in and outside of China for those who can pay handsomely for its luxuries.
Bureaucracy courses through the blood of the Yuan family, resulting in an efficient and experienced administration run by the finest officials.

A little refreshment can add much needed perspective.

Jade is sought by those with an eye for beauty; the skill needed reserves it for those with expensive tastes.
The teachings of Confucius educate the people on how to cultivate their inner and outer life, so that they and their works are greatly improved.

Rule by the sword to evade the ambiguities and trappings of bureaucracy; this government is run with the discipline of a military command.

It is only fair to be granted the spoils of your efforts.

As trade thrives, the development of trade ports takes advantage of the new commercial opportunities to increase your income.

Promising officials are educated in the classics and refinement of character, leaving as talented gentlemen to improve the world with their knowledge.
To train is to study victory in all its forms, and one must practice victory before achieving it.
Animals, a resource in themselves, have many uses. Rearing livestock provides a reliable source of food and income for the people.
To gain traction, a movement needs organisation and a place in which to plan.
Embrace effortless action to achieve harmony with nature.
